document.docAuthor: Lee, Aria L., Capa, María, Dafforn, Katherine A., Hutchings, Pat A. & Murray, Anna
document.masterDocTitle: New records of non-indigenous Branchiomma and Parasabella species (Sabellidae: Annelida) in South Australia highlight the continuing challenges for sabellid taxonomy

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: New records of non-indigenous Branchiomma and Parasabella species (Sabellidae: Annelida) in South Australia highlight the continuing challenges for sabellid taxonomy

Parasabella aberrans , AM W.
37052 (1), Kurnell, NSW, 34°33’S ,
151°13 ʹ 51”E
.

Specimens measured 9–50 mm in body length (thorax and abdomen) and 2–3 mm in width, with 6–8 thoracic and numerous abdominal chaetigers. Live specimens with pale to white radioles with brown spots on longitudinal axes ( Figure 6 (a,b)). Body colour varied from pink to greenish-brown, some specimens with white and brown speckling.

caption.paragraph:
Figure 6.
Parasabella sp. 1
, live specimen. (a) whole body; (b) detail of radiolar crown. AM W.49870.001. AM: Australian Museum voucher number.

subSubSection.paragraph: Radiolar crown with basal lobes semi-circular. Basal membrane absent. 12–22 pairs of radioles, supported by 8–10 vacuolated cells in cross section near base ( Figure 7 ). Radiolar flanges and eyes absent. No observed pinnular appendages on dorsal lip. Posterior peristomial ring reaching almost to base of radioles ( Figure 8 (a)). Ventral sacs absent. Ventral lappet separated by parallel ventral lamellae ( Figure 8 (b,c)). Subdermal peristomial eyes present. Ventral shields conspicuous. First shield wider with M-shaped anterior edge, subsequent shields uniformly sized, in contact with neuropodial tori ( Figure 8 (c)). Superior and inferior collar chaetae elongate and narrowly hooded ( Figure 8 (d)). Superior thoracic chaetae elongate and narrowly hooded. Inferior thoracic chaetae shorter, broadly hooded, hoods twice the width of shaft, and 5–7 times as long as maximum width ( Figures 8 (e) and 9(a,c)), type B ( Capa and Murray 2015a ). Thoracic neuropodial uncini avicular ( Figure 9 (b)) with several rows of uniformly sized teeth above main fang, occupying half length of main fang ( Figure 8 (f,g)); neck shorter than breast, handle 1–1.5 times distance from main fang to breast ( Figure 9 (d)). Thoracic neuropodial companion chaetae enlarged subdistally, covered with several rows of uniformly sized teeth, ending in a thin laterally compressed mucro ( Figure 8 (g,h)). Anterior and posterior abdominal chaetae narrowly hooded ( Figure 4 (i)). Abdominal uncini avicular with several rows of uniformly sized teeth above main fang, occupying half length of main fang ( Figure 8 (j)).

Examination of morphological characters uncovered unique features in the shape and proportion of ventral shields and thoracic uncini, and the number of vacuolated radiolar support cells ( Table 2 ). This species most closely resembles
P. aulaconota
, described from Japanese waters, and concurs with the original ( von Marenzeller 1884 ) and subsequent descriptions ( Johansson 1927 ; Okuda 1939 ), and with a preserved
P. aulaconota
specimen from Japan (AM W.37073). However, we were unable to examine the type specimen of
P. aulaconota
. It also agrees well with the description of
P . cf. aulaconota
of Capa and Murray (2015a) .

caption.paragraph:
Figure 7.
Parasabella sp. 1
, drawing of cross section of radiole showing supporting vacuolated cells (with nuclei). Upper side of drawing shows outer margin of radiole, with columnar epithelial cells indicated in grey. Pinnules shown at the base of the image, with blood vessel in black.

subSubSection.paragraph:
However, phylogenetic analyses, regardless of the marker used, recovered sequences from South Australian specimens nested within the
Parasabella sp. 1
clade ( Figure 2 (a,b)) and separated by small genetic distance if compared with other congeners ( Tables 5 and 6 ), which provides strong evidence of the identity of the specimens. The two specimens (AM W.32563 and AM W.37041) from Florida and Sydney Harbour, Australia , identified as
Parasabella sp. 1
by Capa and Murray (2015a) , were not included in their taxonomic descriptions of that paper as they were very small and had ‘indeterminate morphology’ ( Capa and Murray 2015a , p. 773).

caption.paragraph:
Figure 8.
Parasabella sp. 1
, scanning electron microscope images. (a) anterior thoracic chaetigers and base of radiolar crown, dorsal view. (b) same, lateral view. (c) same, ventral view, with ventral shields in contact with neuropodial tori. (d) collar chaetae, narrowly hooded. (e) mid-thoracic chaetae, narrowly hooded superior notochaete and broadly hooded inferior. (f) detail of mid-thoracic uncini. (g) mid-thoracic chaetae row with companion chaetae. (h) detail of companion chaetae. (i) complete row of uncini and chaetae in abdominal notopodia. (j) detail of abdominal uncini. a: AM W.49871.001. b–j: AM W.49870.001. AM: Australian Museum voucher number.

subSubSection.paragraph: Overall, these results also imply that molecular taxonomy may help classify morphologically complex groups where intraspecific and interspecific variation often overlap.

caption.paragraph:
Figure 9.
Parasabella sp. 1
, micrographs of preserved specimens detailing (a) inferior thoracic chaetae; and (b) thoracic uncini with companion chaetae. From micrographs, line drawings detailing shapes of (c) inferior chaetae; and (d) thoracic uncini. AM W.49870.001. AM: Australian Museum voucher number.

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution USA ( Florida ), Australia ( New South Wales , South Australia ).
